message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The behavioral mechanisms governing collective motion in swarming locusts
Paper Abstract: Collective motion, which is ubiquitous in nature, has traditionally been explained by “self-propelled particle” models from theoretical physics. Here we show, through field, lab, and virtual reality experimentation, that classical models of collective behavior cannot account for how collective motion emerges in marching desert locusts, whose swarms affect the livelihood of millions. In contrast to assumptions made by these models, locusts do not explicitly align with neighbors. While individuals respond to moving-dot stimuli through the optomotor response, this innate behavior does not mediate social response to neighbors. Instead, locust marching behavior, across scales, can be explained by a minimal cognitive framework, which incorporates individuals’ neural representation of bearings to neighbors and internal consensus dynamics for making directional choices. Our findings challenge long-held beliefs about how order can emerge from disorder in animal collectives.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of **consensus dynamics**:

## Definition

Consensus dynamics, also known as agreement dynamics, is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory that studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.

## The Consensus Problem

The goal is to ensure that all agents eventually agree on a certain quantity, despite starting with potentially different initial values.(no content)The consensus problem is a fundamental problem in controlling multi-agent systems.

## Applications

Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space. Additionally, real-world applications often requiring consensus include cloud computing, clock synchronization, PageRank, opinion formation, smart power grids, state estimation, control of UAVs (and multiple robots/agents in general), load balancing, blockchain, and others.

## Related Concepts

Related coordination problems include the rendezvous problem, synchronization, flocking, and formation control, which often rely on similar mathematical foundations and are studied under the broader umbrella of cooperative control.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about self-propelled particles:

## Definition

Self-propelled particles (SPP), also referred to as self-driven particles, are terms used by physicists to describe autonomous agents, which convert energy from the environment into directed or persistent random walk.

## Natural and Artificial Examples

Natural systems which have inspired the study and design of these particles include walking, swimming or flying animals, as well as bacteria, cells, algae and other micro-organisms.(no content)Generally, self-propelled particles often refer to artificial systems such as robots or specifically designed particles such as swimming Janus colloids, bimetallic nanorods, nanomotors and walking grains.

## Collective Behavior

Self-propelled particles interact with each other, which can lead to the emergence of collective behaviours that mimic the self-organization observed with the flocking of birds, the swarming of bugs, the formation of sheep herds, etc.

## Applications and Mechanisms

In the case of directed propulsion, which is driven by a chemical gradient, this is referred to as chemotaxis, observed in biological systems like bacteria quorum sensing and ant pheromone detection, and in synthetic systems like enzyme molecule chemotaxis and enzyme powered hard and soft particles.

## Connection to Active Matter

Active matter is matter composed of large numbers of active "agents", each of which consumes energy in order to move or to exert mechanical forces, and such systems are intrinsically out of thermal equilibrium.

Web search results for query: "collective motion"

Links: [{"title":"Collective motion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_motion"},{"title":"Bacteria collective motion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacteria_collective_motion"},{"title":"Vicsek model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vicsek_model"},{"title":"Clustering of self-propelled particles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clustering_of_self-propelled_particles"},{"title":"Ben Roy Mottelson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Roy_Mottelson"},{"title":"Kuo-Chen Chou - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuo-Chen_Chou"},{"title":"Collective cell migration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_cell_migration"},{"title":"Active matter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_matter"},{"title":"Collective behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_behavior"},{"title":"Collective effects (accelerator physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_effects_(accelerator_physics)"}]

I've performed a web search for "collective motion" and found comprehensive information on this topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Collective motion is defined as the spontaneous emergence of ordered movement in a system consisting of many self-propelled agents.(no content)It can be observed in everyday life, for example in flocks of birds, schools of fish, herds of animals and also in crowds and car traffic.

## Key Characteristics

In a collective motion system, some key characteristics should be included: the units of the system should be similar to each other; the units should be moving with a nearly a constant absolute velocity and are able to change their direction; and the units in the system should be able to interact with fellow units and respond to environmental change.

## Examples and Applications

Collective motion occurs across various scales and contexts:

- **Biological systems:** Silver chloride micromotors, in the presence of UV light, interact with each other at high concentrations and form schools.

- **Cellular level:** Collective cell migration describes the movements of group of cells and the emergence of collective behavior from cell-environment interactions and cell-cell communication.

- **Bacteria:** Bacteria swarming refers to a rapid cellular bacterial surface movement powered by rotating flagella. Key features of swarming bacteria are large-scale swirling and streaming motions.

## Mathematical Modeling

The Vicsek model is a mathematical model used to describe active matter.(no content)This model shows a phase transition from a disordered motion to large-scale ordered motion. At low noise and large density, particles are globally aligned and move in the same direction (collective motion).

I've performed a web search for "collective motion" and found comprehensive information on this topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Collective motion is defined as the spontaneous emergence of ordered movement in a system consisting of many self-propelled agents.(no content)It can be observed in everyday life, for example in flocks of birds, schools of fish, herds of animals and also in crowds and car traffic.

## Key Characteristics

In a collective motion system, some key characteristics should be included: the units of the system should be similar to each other; the units should be moving with a nearly a constant absolute velocity and are able to change their direction; and the units in the system should be able to interact with fellow units and respond to environmental change.

## Examples and Applications

Collective motion occurs across various scales and contexts:

- **Biological systems:** Silver chloride micromotors, in the presence of UV light, interact with each other at high concentrations and form schools.

- **Cellular level:** Collective cell migration describes the movements of group of cells and the emergence of collective behavior from cell-environment interactions and cell-cell communication.

- **Bacteria:** Bacteria swarming refers to a rapid cellular bacterial surface movement powered by rotating flagella. Key features of swarming bacteria are large-scale swirling and streaming motions.

## Mathematical Modeling

The Vicsek model is a mathematical model used to describe active matter.(no content)This model shows a phase transition from a disordered motion to large-scale ordered motion. At low noise and large density, particles are globally aligned and move in the same direction (collective motion).

Web search results for query: "desert locust"

Links: [{"title":"Desert locust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Desert_locust"},{"title":"2019–2022 locust infestation","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019–2022_locust_infestation"},{"title":"Desert Locust Control Organization for Eastern Africa - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Desert_Locust_Control_Organization_for_Eastern_Africa"},{"title":"Locust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locust"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the desert locust:

## Overview

The desert locust is a periodically swarming, short-horned grasshopper found primarily in the deserts and dry areas of northern and eastern Africa, Arabia, and southwest Asia.(no content)It is probably the best known locust species owing to its wide distribution and its ability to migrate over long distances.

## Characteristics and Behavior

Locusts differ from other grasshoppers in their ability to change from a solitary living form into gregarious, highly mobile, adult swarms and hopper bands as their numbers and densities increase.(no content)The sight and smell of other locusts precipitates changes in the locusts' behavior and morphology, as the previously green, nocturnal and solitary creatures become larger, develop black-and-yellow coloring, and begin to seek out other locusts, a process known as gregarization.

## Lifecycle

The lifecycle of the desert locust consists of three stages: the egg, the nymph known as a hopper, and the winged adult.(no content)They have two to five generations per year.

## Threat Level

The desert locust is potentially the most dangerous of the locust pests because of the ability of swarms to fly rapidly across great distances.(no content)Swarms can travel up to 130 km a day in search of new vegetation and moist weather, often propelling themselves by the wind.

## Major Outbreaks

The 2019–2021 upsurge caused significant crop losses in northeast Africa, the Near East, and southwest Asia.

Links: [{"title":"Optomotor response - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optomotor_response"},{"title":"Four-eyed fish - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four-eyed_fish"},{"title":"File:Optomotor Response.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Optomotor_Response.svg"},{"title":"H1 neuron - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H1_neuron"},{"title":"Optogenetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optogenetics"},{"title":"Optokinetic response - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optokinetic_response"},{"title":"Oculomotor apraxia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oculomotor_apraxia"},{"title":"Corneal reflex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corneal_reflex"},{"title":"Oculocardiac reflex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oculocardiac_reflex"},{"title":"Accommodation reflex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Accommodation_reflex"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the optomotor response:

## Definition

The optomotor response is an innate, orienting behavior evoked by whole-field visual motion and is common to fish and insects during locomotion, such as swimming, walking and flying.

## How It Works

The direction of the whole-field coherent motion dictates the direction of the behavioral output (e.g., leftward visual stimuli lead to turning left, and rightward visual stimuli lead to turning right).(no content)For instance, when zebrafish larvae are presented with a sinusoidal black and white grating pattern, the larvae will turn and swim in the direction of the perceived motion.

## Function

The optomotor response is essential for animals to correct unplanned course perturbations while navigating through their environment, such as current shifts around a swimming fish or air gusts around flying insects.(no content)The response is rapid and instinctual, with pure delay times of just 20-40ms for fruit flies in flight.

## Research Applications

The optomotor response is frequently used as a behavioral assay. In zebrafish, the optomotor response is frequently used as a metric of visual performance as it can be reliably evoked from 7 days post fertilization throughout adulthood.(no content)In flies, the optomotor response is used to understand the functional properties of neural circuits in the context of a specific behavior and examine the sensorimotor transformations underlying that behavior.

Web search results for query: "emergence animal behavior"

Links: [{"title":"Flocking (behavior)","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flocking_(behavior)"},{"title":"Swarm behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_behaviour"},{"title":"Emergence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergence"},{"title":"Emergent evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergent_evolution"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Collective animal behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_animal_behavior"},{"title":"History of evolutionary psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_evolutionary_psychology"},{"title":"Behavioral ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_ecology"},{"title":"Emergentism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergentism"},{"title":"Ethology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethology"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of emergence in animal behavior:

## Definition and Core Concept

Collective animal behavior is a form of social behavior involving the coordinated behavior of large groups of similar animals as well as emergent properties of these groups.(no content)From the perspective of the mathematical modeler, emergence is an emergent behavior arising from simple rules that are followed by individuals and does not involve any central coordination.

## Examples in Nature

Several compelling examples demonstrate emergence in animal behavior:

**Flocking and Swarming**: Flocking is an emergent behavior governed by local rules that are followed by individuals and does not involve any central coordination.(no content)Groups of cockroaches can exhibit emergent behavior, in which group or swarm behavior emerges from a simple set of individual interactions.

**Swarm Intelligence**: Swarm intelligence is the collective behavior of decentralized, self-organized systems. Agents follow very simple rules, and although there is no centralized control structure, local interactions between agents lead to the emergence of "intelligent" global behavior, unknown to the individual agents.

## Computer Models

Flocking behavior was simulated on a computer in 1987 by Craig Reynolds with the program Boids. This program simulates simple agents that move according to a set of three basic rules: separation, alignment and cohesion.

## Functions of Animal Groups

Proposed functions of animal aggregations may be grouped into four categories: social and genetic, anti-predator, enhanced foraging, and increased locomotion efficiency.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of emergence in animal behavior:

## Definition and Core Concept

Collective animal behavior is a form of social behavior involving the coordinated behavior of large groups of similar animals as well as emergent properties of these groups.(no content)From the perspective of the mathematical modeler, emergence is an emergent behavior arising from simple rules that are followed by individuals and does not involve any central coordination.

## Examples in Nature

Several compelling examples demonstrate emergence in animal behavior:

**Flocking and Swarming**: Flocking is an emergent behavior governed by local rules that are followed by individuals and does not involve any central coordination.(no content)Groups of cockroaches can exhibit emergent behavior, in which group or swarm behavior emerges from a simple set of individual interactions.

**Swarm Intelligence**: Swarm intelligence is the collective behavior of decentralized, self-organized systems. Agents follow very simple rules, and although there is no centralized control structure, local interactions between agents lead to the emergence of "intelligent" global behavior, unknown to the individual agents.

## Computer Models

Flocking behavior was simulated on a computer in 1987 by Craig Reynolds with the program Boids. This program simulates simple agents that move according to a set of three basic rules: separation, alignment and cohesion.

## Functions of Animal Groups

Proposed functions of animal aggregations may be grouped into four categories: social and genetic, anti-predator, enhanced foraging, and increased locomotion efficiency.

I've completed a web search for "virtual reality." Here's a comprehensive overview based on the results:

## What is Virtual Reality?

Virtual reality (VR) is a simulated experience that employs 3D near-eye displays and pose tracking to give the user an immersive feel of a virtual world.(no content)A person using virtual reality equipment is able to look around the artificial world, move around in it, and interact with virtual features or items.

## How VR is Created

The effect is commonly created by VR headsets consisting of a head-mounted display with a small screen in front of the eyes but can also be created through specially designed rooms with multiple large screens.(no content)Virtual reality typically incorporates auditory and video feedback but may also allow other types of sensory and force feedback through haptic technology.

## Applications

Applications of virtual reality include entertainment (particularly video games), education (such as medical, safety, or military training), research and business (such as virtual meetings). Additional applications span architectural and urban design, industrial designs, restorative nature experiences, healthcare and clinical therapies, digital marketing and activism, engineering and robotics, entertainment, virtual communities, fine arts, heritage and archaeology, occupational safety, as well as social science and psychology.

## History

The earliest published use of the term "virtual reality" is from 1958 in the English translation of a French book.(no content)Widespread adoption of the term "virtual reality" in the popular media is attributed to Jaron Lanier, who in the late 1980s designed some of the first business-grade virtual reality hardware.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

todos.content: Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.
todos.activeForm: Reading and classifying paper

todos.content: List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.
todos.activeForm: Listing and analyzing triples from title/abstract

todos.content: For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.
todos.activeForm: Searching for Wikipedia articles for all triples

todos.content: Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
todos.activeForm: Editing triples_output.json with all triple data

todos.content: Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py
todos.activeForm: Running validation script

todos.content: If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
todos.activeForm: Fixing validation errors if needed
